intro: Palhinhaea mariana, commonly known as the Florida palmetto, is a species of palm native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its dense, fan-shaped leaves and stout, clustered stems. The plant typically grows in wetlands and swampy areas, where it thrives in moist, acidic soils. Its flowers are small and clustered, and it produces berries that are an important food source for local wildlife. Palhinhaea mariana plays a vital role in the ecological balance of its native habitat.
